text:
'Would anyone miss me?' Troubled teen commits suicide at children's home after cry for help on Facebook 'ignored' Care watchdogs are set to examine the 13-year-old's death after she posted about bullying and depression online Share Kirsty McGregor shared her struggle with depression on social media (Photo: Daily Record) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! A troubled 13-year-old took her life while she was living at a children's home after posting on Facebook about having no real friends. 
Care watchdogs are set to examine the teenager's death after her worrying cries for help on social media appeared to be ignored. 
Tragic Kirsty McGregor died in hospital in Dunoon, Argyll, after being found injured at the town’s Dunclutha Children’s Home just before New Year. 
It’s understood the keen dancer and gymnast took her own life . 
She had shared her struggle with depression and self harming on social media. 
A source close to the tragedy has called for a public inquiry into Kirsty’s death, saying valuable lessons could be learned in dealing with vulnerable youngsters in care, reports the Daily Record . Kirsty had filled out a form online saying she had been bullied and was depressed (Photo: Daily Record) 
The source said: “The system failed to keep this poor girl safe. She was a known self-harmer and she should have had extra care.” 
Another picture she shared read: “I’m that one friend. The one who walks behind everyone else. 
"The one that no one really notices in the group. The one that people forget to include. The one that is always there for others but never has anyone to be there for me.” 
As well as sharing a video admitting to being self-harmer, Kirsty filled out a quiz online saying she had been bullied and admitting to feeling depressed. 
The day after her suicide on December 30, friends shared pictures of the teenager and tributes. 
One close pal wrote on a picture of Kirsty: “Gone but never forgotten.” Another added: “She will be missed.” Kirsty's Facebook post before she committed suicide (Photo: Daily Record) Read More Mum releases shocking pictures of schoolboy left for dead after thugs smashed his skull 
A police spokeswoman confirmed her death was not suspicious. 
She said: “We can confirm that at around 3.40pm on Friday, December 30, police received a report of a 13-year-old girl being found injured within a property on Marine Parade, Dunoon. 
“She was taken by ambulance to the Cowal Community Hospital where she later died. 
“The girl has been formally identified and relatives have been informed. 
“The death is not being treated as suspicious and a report has been submitted to the Procurator Fiscal.” 
A review into the tragedy is being compiled by Argyll and Bute Council and will be sent to the Care Inspectorate, who will decide whether further investigations need to be carried out. 
The Care Inspectorate said the case would be reviewed. Kirsty was living in a children's home when she took her life (Photo: Daily Record) Read More Man who lost pal in horrific Ayia Napa stabbing recalls moment knifemen attacked 
A spokesman said: “The death of a child is always a tragedy and our thoughts are with those affected at this difficult time. 
“We await the appropriate report from the local authority into this case which we will review in due course. 
“Where there is learning to be taken from this we will discuss it with the partners involved to help ensure that the care and support of looked after children is of a standard which they have a right to expect. 
“We continue to work closely with the care service and local authority to ensure that young people are safe – and that rights are respected and their needs met. 
“Anyone with a concern about a care service can contact us on 0345 600 9527.” 
Kirsty’s relatives did not want to speak about the tragedy. Samaritans (116 123) operates a 24-hour service available every day of the year. If you prefer to write down how you’re feeling, or if you’re worried about being overheard on the phone, you can email Samaritans at jo@samaritans.org. Like us on Facebook
